abstract.text: A graphical representation of the state of biometric authentication.

inlineContent.text: In the view that you use to manage authentication, add a local authentication view
as a subview and provide it with an
instance. For example, you can do this in the

code: // Add more subviews and layout constraints...

inlineContent.text: When the view appears, call the context’s
The local authentication view displays an icon that depends on the type of authentication
you request, and the types of authentication that the system supports. For example,
for a device that supports Touch ID, if you request the
policy, like in the example above, the view displays the familiar finger print icon:
In the case above, if the user has a connected Apple Watch, that authentication mechanism
works as well. If you limit the authentication to the
policy, the icon shows an Apple Watch in profile:
You can include other content around this icon that suits your app. The system also
displays a message on the Touch Bar or on the user’s Apple Watch, if appropriate.
When the evaluation succeeds, the icon transitions into a checkmark:
If you call the evaluation without first attaching it to a local authentication view,
the system shows a standard authentication alert instead.

abstract.text: Present a standard local authentication view icon in a custom authentication view.
A graphical representation of the state of biometric authentication.
The local authentication context associated with the authentication view.
The size of the local authentication view user interface element.
Creates a new authentication icon that reflects the current authentication state.
Creates a new authentication icon that reflects the current authentication state,
using a specified size.
A mechanism for evaluating authentication policies and access controls.
Evaluates the specified policy.
User authentication with either biometry or Apple Watch.
User authentication with Apple Watch.
The infrastructure for drawing, printing, and handling events in an app.
The complete list of properties and methods for accessible elements.
A role-based protocol that declares the minimum interface necessary to interact with an assistive app.
A set of methods that defines a way to add animation to an existing class with a minimum of API impact.
A set of methods for getting and setting the appearance attributes of a view.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A set of methods that the destination object (or recipient) of a dragged image must implement.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
Methods that responder subclasses implement to support key binding commands, such as inserting tabs and newlines, or moving the insertion point.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A protocol that marks classes to restore the state of your app to continue a user activity.
A set of methods used to associate a unique identifier with objects in your user interface.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
